articles.headline: Old Saturn Plant Could Get a Second Chance
articles.snippet: General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union agreed to bring jobs back to a plant in Tennessee.
articles.abstract: General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union agreed to bring jobs back to a plant in Tennessee.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRING HILL, Tenn. — When General Motors stopped building cars here two years ago, as the auto industry hit rock bottom and tens of thousands of assembly-line jobs evaporated nationwide, Chad Poynor packed up and moved to Michigan to keep working at another plant.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Spy Agency Is Tied to Attack on U.S. Embassy
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s intelligence agency aided insurgents who attacked the embassy in Kabul last week, said Adm. Mike Mullen, the departing chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s intelligence agency aided insurgents who attacked the embassy in Kabul last week, said Adm. Mike Mullen, the departing chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top military official said Thursday that Pakistan’s spy agency played a direct role in supporting the insurgents who carried out the deadly attack on the American Embassy in Kabul last week. It was the most serious charge that the United States has leveled against Pakistan in the decade that America has been at war in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Meg Whitman Is Named Hewlett-Packard Chief
articles.snippet: The company said its strategy to transform its business was sound, but it needed new leadership to carry it out.
articles.abstract: The company said its strategy to transform its business was sound, but it needed new leadership to carry it out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard replaced its embattled chief executive on Thursday with the former eBay chief executive Meg Whitman, saying that the company’s strategy to transform its business was sound, but that it needed new leadership to carry out the plan.

articles.headline: Facebook as Tastemaker
articles.snippet: Facebook is where you go to see what your friends are up to. Now it wants to be a force that shapes what you watch, hear, read and buy.
articles.abstract: Facebook is where you go to see what your friends are up to. Now it wants to be a force that shapes what you watch, hear, read and buy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, the Web’s biggest social network, is where you go to see what your friends are up to. Now it wants to be a force that shapes what you watch, hear, read and buy.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Spain’s Banking Mess
articles.snippet: Bad real estate loans are dragging down Spanish banks, much as they did American banks. But from there, the stories diverge.
articles.abstract: Bad real estate loans are dragging down Spanish banks, much as they did American banks. But from there, the stories diverge.

articles.headline: More Offices Let Workers Choose Their Own Devices
articles.snippet: In the consumerization of I.T., fewer companies are dictating which smartphones, tablets and other electronics must be used by their employees.
articles.abstract: In the consumerization of I.T., fewer companies are dictating which smartphones, tablets and other electronics must be used by their employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Throughout the information age, the corporate I.T. department has stood at the chokepoint of office technology with a firm hand on what equipment and software employees use in the workplace.

articles.headline: A Gold Rush Wanes as Hedge Funds Sell
articles.snippet: After climbing for about two years, the prices of gold and some other commodities are falling, and hedge funds are unwinding their positions.
articles.abstract: After climbing for about two years, the prices of gold and some other commodities are falling, and hedge funds are unwinding their positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the smart money fleeing gold?

articles.headline: In Rush to Assist a Solar Company, U.S. Missed Signs
articles.snippet: Industry analysts and government auditors say the administration failed to take note of trouble already evident in the solar energy marketplace.
articles.abstract: Industry analysts and government auditors say the administration failed to take note of trouble already evident in the solar energy marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s visit to the Solyndra solar panel factory in California last year was choreographed down to the last detail — the 20-by-30-foot American flags, the corporate banners hung just so, the special lighting, even coffee and doughnuts for the Secret Service detail.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and John M. Broder

articles.headline: U.S. Pushes Europe to Act With Force on Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: President Obama is lobbying Germany and France to take coordinated measures to prevent Greece’s woes from engulfing its neighbors.
articles.abstract: President Obama is lobbying Germany and France to take coordinated measures to prevent Greece’s woes from engulfing its neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, increasingly alarmed by the spillover effects of Europe’s financial crisis, has begun an intensive lobbying campaign to persuade Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and other leaders to ramp up efforts to stem any contagion from the debt crisis in Greece.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Binyamin Appelbaum
